alert.note: Alert for Lewis (Washington) Issued by the National Weather Service

info.headline: Flood Warning issued December 05 at 8:24AM PST until December 07 at 5:38AM PST by NWS Seattle
info.description: ...The National Weather Service in Seattle WA has issued a Flood Warning for the following rivers in Washington... Skagit River Near Mt. Vernon affecting Skagit County. Cowlitz River At Randle affecting Lewis County. Newaukum River Near Chehalis affecting Lewis County. .Heavy rain will continue in the Washington Cascades through this afternoon. Another 2 to 4 inches of rain is forecast before the rate rates ease late in the day. For the North West Region...including Mt. Vernon...Major flooding is forecast. For the South West Region...including Randle...Moderate flooding is forecast. For the Chehalis River Basin Region...including Chehalis...Moderate flooding is forecast. ...FLOOD WARNING IN EFFECT FROM THIS AFTERNOON TO EARLY THURSDAY MORNING... * WHAT...Moderate flooding is forecast. * WHERE...Newaukum River near Chehalis. * WHEN...From this afternoon to early Thursday morning. * IMPACTS...At 204.5 feet, deep and hazardous flood waters will inundate many roads and residential and commercial areas along the Newaukum River and its forks. Impacted roadways and surrounding areas include SR 508, Jackson Hwy. and Tune, Rush, Sommerville, Griel, Hamilton, Tauscher, Guerrier, Kirkland, Macomber, Rice, Senn, Lucas Creek, Middle Fork and North Fork, Bishop, Shorey, Labree, Gish, Yates Roads. A stage of 204.5 feet on the Newaukum roughly corresponds to Phase 3 flood in the Lewis County flood system. * ADDITIONAL DETAILS... - At 7:45 AM PST Tuesday the stage was 198.6 feet. - Flood stage is 202.5 feet. - Forecast...The river is expected to rise above flood stage late this afternoon to a crest of 205.1 feet late tonight. It will then fall below flood stage tomorrow evening. - Flood History...No available flood history. - http://www.weather.gov/safety/flood &&
info.instruction: Turn around, don`t drown when encountering flooded roads. Most flood deaths occur in vehicles. Motorists should not attempt to drive around barricades or drive cars through flooded areas. Caution is urged when walking near riverbanks. Additional information is available at www.weather.gov. The next statement will be issued by this afternoon at 445 PM PST.
